article:
2022 Sri Lankan Protests

The 2022 Sri Lankan protests were a series of mass protests and demonstrations against the government of Sri Lanka, led by President Gotabaya Rajapaksa and his administration. The protests began in March 2022 and continued until July 2022, resulting in the resignation of President Rajapaksa and the appointment of a new government.

#Background

Sri Lanka has been facing a severe economic crisis since 2021, with high levels of inflation, food and fuel shortages, and a significant decline in foreign currency reserves. The government's handling of the crisis, including its refusal to accept International Monetary Fund (IMF) assistance and its decision to default on foreign debt payments, exacerbated the situation.

The Rajapaksa family has been in power in Sri Lanka since 2005, with Gotabaya Rajapaksa serving as President since 2019. The family has been accused of corruption, nepotism, and human rights abuses, which has led to widespread discontent among the population.

#Timeline

##March

The protests began on March 15, 2022, with a small group of demonstrators gathering outside the President's House in Colombo, demanding the resignation of the government. The protests gained momentum over the next few days, with thousands of people joining in from across the country.

##April

###Declaration of state of emergency

On April 1, 2022, President Rajapaksa declared a state of emergency, giving the military sweeping powers to arrest and detain protesters. The move was widely condemned by human rights groups and opposition parties.

###Social media blocks

The government also blocked social media platforms, including Facebook, Twitter, and WhatsApp, in an attempt to prevent the spread of information about the protests.

###Cabinet resignation

On April 3, 2022, the entire Cabinet, except for the President's brother, Basil Rajapaksa, resigned en masse. However, the President refused to accept their resignations.

###Reconvening of Parliament

On April 5, 2022, Parliament reconvened after a brief adjournment, with opposition parties demanding the resignation of the government. However, the government refused to budge.

###"Occupy Galle Face"

On April 9, 2022, protesters launched the "Occupy Galle Face" movement, setting up a permanent protest camp outside the Presidential Secretariat in Colombo.

###Mynagogama

On April 12, 2022, protesters in Mynagogama, a suburb of Colombo, clashed with police, resulting in several injuries.

###19 April: Rambukkana incident

On April 19, 2022, police opened fire on protesters in Rambukkana, killing one person and injuring several others. The incident sparked widespread outrage and calls for the resignation of the government.

###28 April: Island-wide token strike

On April 28, 2022, an island-wide token strike was held, with businesses and schools closing in support of the protests.

##May

###HoruGoGama protests

On May 1, 2022, protesters launched the "HoruGoGama" movement, setting up a permanent protest camp outside the Prime Minister's official residence in Colombo.

###Black Monday attacks on protesters

On May 9, 2022, government supporters launched a series of attacks on protesters in Colombo, resulting in several injuries.

###Resignation of Mahinda Rajapaksa

On May 9, 2022, Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa resigned, following pressure from opposition parties and protesters.

###Deployment of military

On May 10, 2022, the military was deployed to Colombo to quell the protests, resulting in several injuries and arrests.

###Founding of No-Deal-Gama

On May 20, 2022, protesters launched the "No-Deal-Gama" movement, setting up a permanent protest camp outside the Presidential Secretariat in Colombo.

##June

The protests continued throughout June, with protesters demanding the resignation of President Rajapaksa and the establishment of a new government.

##July

###9 July: Storming of President's House

On July 9, 2022, protesters stormed the President's House in Colombo, forcing President Rajapaksa to flee.

###13 July: Appointment of Acting President

On July 13, 2022, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe was appointed Acting President, following the resignation of President Rajapaksa.

###14–15 July: President Rajapaksa's resignation

On July 14-15, 2022, President Rajapaksa resigned, marking the end of the Rajapaksa regime.

###20–22 July: Under the new President, Galle Face raid

On July 20-22, 2022, the military launched a raid on the Galle Face protest camp, resulting in several injuries and arrests.

##August

The protests continued throughout August, with protesters demanding the establishment of a new government and the prosecution of those responsible for human rights abuses.

##September

The protests continued throughout September, with protesters demanding the establishment of a new government and the prosecution of those responsible for human rights abuses.

##November

The protests continued throughout November, with protesters demanding the establishment of a new government and the prosecution of those responsible for human rights abuses.

#International protests

Protests were also held in several countries, including the United States, Canada, and Australia, in solidarity with the Sri Lankan protesters.

#Reactions

##New government

The new government, led by President Wickremesinghe, has promised to establish a commission to investigate human rights abuses and to prosecute those responsible.

##Opposition

The opposition parties have demanded the establishment of a new government and the prosecution of those responsible for human rights abuses.

##International

The international community has condemned the human rights abuses committed by the Rajapaksa regime and has called for the establishment of a new government.

#Departures to foreign states

Several members of the Rajapaksa family, including Basil Rajapaksa and Namal Rajapaksa, have fled the country, amid fears of prosecution.

#See also

* 2022 Sri Lankan economic crisis

article:
2022–23 Bangladesh Premier League

The 2022–23 Bangladesh Premier League (also known as BPL 9) was the ninth edition of the Bangladesh Premier League (BPL), the top-level professional Twenty20 cricket league in Bangladesh. The tournament was organized by the Bangladesh Cricket Board (BCB) and featured seven teams. The league stage of the tournament was held from January 6 to February 14, 2023, while the playoffs were held from February 16 to February 18, 2023.

# Draft and squads

The players' draft for the 2022–23 season was held on November 23, 2022. The seven teams participating in the tournament were: Comilla Victorians, Dhaka Dominators, Fortune Barishal, Khulna Tigers, Rangpur Riders, Sylhet Strikers, and Chattogram Challengers. Each team was allowed to retain a maximum of three players from their previous season's squad. The remaining players were selected through the draft.

# Venues

The tournament was held across four venues in Bangladesh: Sher-e-Bangla National Cricket Stadium in Dhaka, Zahur Ahmed Chowdhury Stadium in Chittagong, Sylhet International Cricket Stadium in Sylhet, and Bangladesh Krira Shiksha Pratisthan Ground in Dhaka.

# Teams and standings

## Points Table

| Team | Pld | W | L | NR | Pts | NRR |
| Comilla Victorians | 12 | 9 | 3 | 0 | 18 | +0.737 |
| Sylhet Strikers | 12 | 9 | 3 | 0 | 18 | +0.544 |
| Chattogram Challengers | 12 | 7 | 5 | 0 | 14 | +0.251 |
| Rangpur Riders | 12 | 7 | 5 | 0 | 14 | -0.076 |
| Dhaka Dominators | 12 | 6 | 6 | 0 | 12 | +0.285 |
| Fortune Barishal | 12 | 5 | 7 | 0 | 10 | -0.391 |
| Khulna Tigers | 12 | 1 | 11 | 0 | 2 | -1.025 |

# League stage

The league stage of the tournament was divided into five phases, with each phase featuring matches at a different venue.

## Phase 1 (Dhaka)

The first phase of the league stage was held at the Sher-e-Bangla National Cricket Stadium in Dhaka from January 6 to January 12, 2023. Comilla Victorians topped the table after the first phase, winning three of their four matches.

## Phase 2 (Chittagong)

The second phase of the league stage was held at the Zahur Ahmed Chowdhury Stadium in Chittagong from January 13 to January 19, 2023. Sylhet Strikers moved to the top of the table after the second phase, winning three of their four matches.

## Phase 3 (Dhaka)

The third phase of the league stage was held at the Sher-e-Bangla National Cricket Stadium in Dhaka from January 20 to January 26, 2023. Comilla Victorians regained the top spot after the third phase, winning two of their three matches.

## Phase 4 (Sylhet)

The fourth phase of the league stage was held at the Sylhet International Cricket Stadium in Sylhet from January 27 to February 2, 2023. Sylhet Strikers took the top spot again after the fourth phase, winning two of their three matches.

## Phase 5 (Dhaka)

The fifth and final phase of the league stage was held at the Bangladesh Krira Shiksha Pratisthan Ground in Dhaka from February 3 to February 14, 2023. Comilla Victorians finished at the top of the table after the league stage, winning nine of their 12 matches.

# Playoffs

The playoffs of the tournament featured the top four teams in the points table. The playoffs were held from February 16 to February 18, 2023.

## Eliminator

The eliminator match was played between the third-placed Chattogram Challengers and the fourth-placed Rangpur Riders on February 16, 2023. Chattogram Challengers won the match by 6 wickets and advanced to the qualifier 2.

## Qualifiers

The qualifier 1 match was played between the top-placed Comilla Victorians and the second-placed Sylhet Strikers on February 16, 2023. Comilla Victorians won the match by 5 wickets and advanced to the final. The qualifier 2 match was played between Chattogram Challengers and Sylhet Strikers on February 17, 2023. Sylhet Strikers won the match by 7 wickets and advanced to the final.

## Final

The final match of the tournament was played between Comilla Victorians and Sylhet Strikers on February 18, 2023. Comilla Victorians won the match by 4 wickets and became the champions of the 2022–23 Bangladesh Premier League.

# Statistics

## Most runs

The top run-scorers in the tournament were:

| Player | Team | Runs |
| Johnson Charles | Sylhet Strikers | 516 |
| Najmul Hossain Shanto | Comilla Victorians | 516 |
| Liton Das | Comilla Victorians | 418 |

## Most wickets

The top wicket-takers in the tournament were:

| Player | Team | Wickets |
| Tanvir Islam | Sylhet Strikers | 18 |
| Shakib Al Hasan | Fortune Barishal | 17 |
| Mustafizur Rahman | Comilla Victorians | 16 |

## Highest team totals

The highest team totals in the tournament were:

| Team | Total | Opponent |
| Sylhet Strikers | 239/4 | Chattogram Challengers |
| Comilla Victorians | 236/3 | Rangpur Riders |
| Chattogram Challengers | 223/7 | Khulna Tigers |

# Prizes and awards

The champions of the tournament, Comilla Victorians, received a prize money of ৳2 crore (US$190,000). The runner-up team, Sylhet Strikers, received a prize money of ৳1 crore (US$95,000). The player of the tournament award was given to Johnson Charles of Sylhet Strikers.
